bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 7, 1908

div1.p: Agramonte writes about a case of yellow fever he observed in Daiquiri, Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 7, 1908
div1.opener:
Venient, July 7/08
Maj. J. R. Kean U.S.A.
Havana
FROM GEN. J.R. KEAN
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Upon my arrival at Santiago
last night, I learned that the tug “Colon”
was to sail for Daiguir's at 3 a.m.

In my desire to arrive here soonest
possible, I went on board immediately and
slept in a bed-buggy cot until 6 a.m.
that we reached Daiquir's.

I 'phoned to Cartaya who has met
me at the Hospital where I can vouch
for the existence of one case of yellow
fever and every thing seems to indicate
that other cases have preceded this one.
The case is that of José Alvarez Vazquez,
Spaniard, 17 yrs old, 18 months in Cuba
and worked at the art, with the same gang
So which the “posted” case belonged.

This boy has black vomit, isterus, great
quantity of albumin, Temp. 37. 8 P.70
and seems to be in the 8th day of his disease.

He seems to be improving now but should
2
he die within the next two or three days
I shall autopsy his body.-

Of course, I have had no time to see
Capt. Thomasen who, I am told, is
expected here to-day together with
Agostini. Cartaya has to go back to
Santiago to-day because he brought &
very little clothes with him not expect-
ing he have had to remain so long.-

Conditions for a good campaign
are rather unsatisfactory, but of this
I shall write you more later on and
I expect to leave here only after the
work is reorganized to the best of
my ability.-

It is onlyalready 11 a.m. and I have been
unable to take a both since I left
home. I write in great hurry to let this
note go back by the “Colon” which leaves at
one.-
div1.closer:
Sincere Agramonte
Daiquini
July 7
Dr A. Agramonte
AC
Ag to Am
